Robin of Loxley.Action: Takes back his battle helmet and fits it on his head promptly, preparing himself for battle.
Stares at the pot of water with dawning realization as its surface starts to sway, showing alertness and situational awareness.
Observes the changing conditions carefully and responds to the danger by readying for combat and attack.
Has been robbing, pillaging, and murdering noblemen and Normans for six months with enough success to be widely known and feared.
Maintains popular support among peasants and townsfolk by selectively distributing spoils to keep his whereabouts secret.
His actions have significantly reduced the population of Nottingham due to the disorder he causes.
Shoots an arrow that cuts a rope to trigger a trap, aimed at capturing an enemy rather than harming indiscriminately.
Whistles to call his horse which responds and comes galloping to him promptly.
Runs quickly towards his horse while glancing back to monitor pursuers, showing awareness and urgency.
Leaps bareback onto his horse, takes control of the reins, spins the horse around and rides off at speed escaping enemies.
Fails to recognize or avoid the swinging log trap, is knocked off his horse and knocked unconscious.
Uses captured Tornham as target practice, shooting arrows near and at him while mocking him and encouraging laughter among his men.
Fires an arrow with precise skill, splitting hairs atop Tornham’s head.
Responds to Tornham’s demands with confident humor and control over the situation, maintaining morale among his men.
Expresses strong distrust for the courts but does not immediately present an alternative legal strategy.
Is targeted and blamed by others (Hugo curses him), indicating he is a capable adversary.
No direct action or statement by Robin in this excerpt; absence of visible response or presence.
Greets Marian with a hug and expresses relief and warmth despite being half-asleep.
Shows concern that his men could have harmed Marian due to their vigilance.
Wakes up abruptly upon hearing Marian has arrived, prioritizing her warning over his own rest.
Stops Little John from stabbing Tornham, choosing to hear him out.
Narrows his eyes and questions Tornham aggressively.
Releases the Sheriff despite tension and mistrust from his men.
Prefers to spend time with Marian rather than immediately seeking to clear his name.

Cuts off Tornham to change the subject abruptly, possibly avoiding deeper investigation.
Shows self-awareness and vulnerability about his relationship with Marian and life in the woods.

Shows restraint by deciding not to kill Tornham because of Marian's disapproval, indicating self-control and considered decision-making.
Admits to being drunk while making a tactical observation, which may undermine reliability.

Accepts help from Madman Haley and Marian to escape imprisonment without resistance but shows gratitude and calmness upon release.
Grasps arrows lodged in his own body and uses them as weapons to stab an opponent, turning a dire situation to his advantage.
Puts two arrows into Sir Guy, the murderer, demonstrating skill in archery and effective action against an adversary.
Wounds the Sheriff of Nottingham, showing bravery and capability in opposing tyranny.
Discovered Gisborne’s hidden sanctum of horrors, aiding King Richard to regain his castle, showing intelligence and strategic impact.
Portrayed as a legendary hero who inspires pride and embodies hope, suggesting consistent competence and leadership.
Develops and executes a brilliant counter-mining stratagem that defeats the rebellious locals and impresses King Richard.
Successfully earns a personal congratulatory message from the King, reflecting royal recognition of his skill.
Fights and wins a desperate victory over the Army defending Cyprus, showcasing tactical and combat competence.

Shows defiance and bitterness towards corrupt authority but remains open in explaining his position to Tornham.

Allows a captured enemy (Tornham) to live and be released despite provocation.

Holds Tornham captive in Sherwood Forest, enabling proof of his alibi and thus skillfully avoiding false accusation.

Robin Hood's men hijack belongings skillfully and strategically, indicating competence in planning and execution.

Considers games and books idle pursuits and shows no interest in them, implying a focus on more practical or serious matters.

Wakes up immediately and reacts quickly when alerted of Marian's arrival, shakes the woman to get out, and manages a quick escape down the tree tent ladder to meet Marian despite being half-asleep and disheveled.

Fights fiercely and bravely against Gisborne without backing down despite being overwhelmed.

Engages in a brutal, intense physical fight with Gisborne, showing no mercy or restraint.
Keeps struggling and resisting even when being overwhelmed and having his head forced into the mud.
Trips opponent to prevent a lethal blow and quickly recovers to rearm and retaliate by wounding opponent's armor.
Adapts to losing his sword by using his shield offensively to stab opponent and momentarily gain advantage.
Successfully dodges a deadly axe strike and counters with a head-butt, forcing opponent to drop weapon.
Engages in brutal hand-to-hand combat, showing resilience and determination despite being outmatched physically.
Ultimately fails to free himself from a headlock and is subdued by opponent, losing consciousness.
Explodes out of the mud and attacks Gisborne in a desperate surprise attack to protect himself and interrupt the threatening situation.
Suddenly explodes out of the mud and successfully immobilizes Guy of Gisborne by choking him, using surprise and physical skill.
Continues fighting fiercely even while being dragged away by multiple guards.
Does not manage to escape or turn the tide despite a brave attempt, is pulled off and defeated in this encounter.
Shows gratitude and affection by taking Marian into his arms and giving her a long, heartfelt kiss after being freed.
Suddenly appears across the courtyard, quickly grabs a bow and arrow, and aims accurately at the fleeing enemy Gisborne, demonstrating quick reflexes and marksmanship.
Races after Gisborne but is cut off by fighting and unable to prevent his escape, indicating a limitation in controlling the chaotic situation.

Trains Tornham, improving his archery skills despite Tornham being an amateur.
